review_title: A Valuable Asset to the Team
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Irvine, CA
pros: Our graduate research assistant has been an exceptional addition to our team, showcasing unwavering dedication and a remarkable ability to contribute effectively. Their positive attitude, strong work ethic, and excellent problem-solving skills have greatly enhanced our research endeavors. With their outstanding commitment and impressive adaptability, they consistently deliver high-quality results. Their collaborative nature and exceptional communication skills have fostered a productive and harmonious work environment, inspiring their peers and making them a true asset to our team.
cons: While our graduate research assistant has undoubtedly made valuable contributions to our team, there are a few areas where they could further develop their skills. One area for improvement is time management, as occasionally there have been instances of missed deadlines or a need for reminders. Additionally, their attention to detail could be heightened to ensure thoroughness in their work. However, it is important to note that these areas are minor and do not overshadow their dedication, teamwork, and overall positive impact on our research projects. With a little focus on refining these skills, our graduate research assistant has the potential to become an even stronger asset to our team in the future.

review_title: A great place to do research as a Ph.D. researcher
pros: I joined UC Irvine as a 3rd year Ph.D. student in Fall 2018. So, I did not do any coursework there. I just continued my Ph.D. research. I think it's a great place to do research for many reasons. First of all, the university invests a lot of money in the research infrastructure- building labs, hiring fantastic young researchers as assistant professors or research scientists, arranging seminars etc. Secondly, they provided low-cost housing options to us which removes a lot of stress from Ph.D. researchers whose salaries are typically low. In addition, the other facilities like sports fields, gyms were also very good. If you wanna relax, just drive 10-15 miles to Newport or Huntington beaches and enjoy the calm ocean :). Overall, I had a fun time there.
cons: There are a lot of students. Naturally, the administrative processing was a little slower.

review_title: A Lot of bureaucracy and pay does not meet cost of living in area
pros: Everyone was very nice and the campus was lovely.
cons: Postdocs never get paid enough anywhere, but Irvine is a particularly expensive place to live which made it extra difficult. Also, everything was very bureaucratic and required going through a lot of different people and departments. Getting on-boarded and health insurance and even my email set up was all very complicated. Even something as simple as "can I bring my fully trained 10 lb hypoallergenic dog to my private office since I am working here 12+ hours a day and can't afford to live within 45 minutes of campus" was met with "well, I am fine with it, but you need to check with these 8 other people in 3 different departments first..." Again, they were very nice about it, but it was definitely much more ridged and corporate feeling than any other college I had ever been at.

review_title: Overall a great place to work
pros:
- Friendly people who generally want to do a great job.
- Great benefits, time off, holidays, etc.
- Fun work and the ability to collaborate with so many different departments and entities.
cons:
- Some departments have leaders/directors who are absolutely unequipped professionally, mentally, and emotionally to lead and manage large teams towards success.
- HR/OEOD really do NOT have the best interest of the employee in mind when dealing with complaints involving senior-level leadership. They talk a great game that they really care and that they will investigate the issue at hand, but really they are just checking boxes and sweep things under the rug. I truly hope it doesn't backfire on them in terms of a lawsuit later on down the line. My advice is to not even bother reporting anything. I was retaliated against and it forced me to leave before my mental health got worse. I truly loved working there too. 
- The current VC of the Wellness cluster is amazing. I would have liked to work for her since she seems like a go-getter.

pros: I loved working here. The staff is super friendly and will genuinely try to get to know you on a personal level. There are weekly trainings that will obviously help you assist your students with their career-related questions, but will also help you navigate the job search process. The amount of resources UCI can offer students is something I took for granted after I left, and you'll be intimately familiar with these tools as a peer consultant. Make sure to take advantage of them while you can!
cons: There's not many downsides to working here. You will have to work on tasks and assignments outside of work hours (you will be paid for these tasks), so this position sometimes felt like another class. If you have a loaded schedule, make sure to organize your time well so you don't fall behind in your responsibilities.

pros: The benefits such as medical, dental and vision are great, as well as, vacation and sick time accrual. There are a lot of paid holidays per year which helps with work-life balance.
cons: Each school on campus is not fully funded by UCI which means each school has different levels of staffing depending on additional funding brought in by academic/research employees. This results in staff members, such as an HR Generalist, in one school having fewer responsibilities when compared to another school that has less funding. The HR Generalist in the less funded school does more and gets paid less. Many management employees are promoted lower staff who do not have the leadership skills and people skills to be effective in their new title. If they have a lot of time at UCI but are ineffective in their management position, they are promoted to higher leadership positions that may not require leadership of staff at a much higher salary. The Deans are professors who do not know how to lead staff and/or do not see staff as being important to the success of the school. The UC system has changed internal systems which has resulted in a significant increase in time staff need to complete their duties. The increase is not acknowledged by Central Administrative Leadership and the President's Office. Even though schools meet annually with the Chancellor and continually express their frustration with the lack of staffing no additional funding is provided to hire more staff. There has been a significant increase of staff medical leaves due to stress and burnout.

cons:
This review is specific to TAing during the COVID pandemic mostly, but it really betrayed how UCI views the importance of student health. Most professors took months to start being empathetic towards students' struggles during COVID, and their empathy only lasted a few months, anyhow. From my POV as a TA, and a graduate student myself, UCI chose to value grades over student mental health during a very traumatic situation for many of them.

Pay-wise, if you have a family, if you're not able to live in the subsidized school housing (there's a time limit on it too), or you just have any big expenses.. the salary will be really tight or too low. Living in Irvine is expensive.

review_title: Support for disabled students, but not employees.
pros: Has their own internal temps dept. instead of using an outside service and it's a good way to get a foot in the door at that employer. It was a great place to work as long as I was fast, strong, and able-bodied. For most of the time I worked there I believed that we were a good team, that my work had meaning and that I was valued as an employee.
cons: Campus and medical center have identical job names and descriptions but the environment was completely different. Campus was much more relaxed, more supportive of career goals, more options to participate in campus life - such as a huge new gym facility. Medical center employees had their own life, healthcare staff theirs, very insular and limited. And unfortunately, I discovered that for healthcare they were not supportive of disabled people in the workplace. Students on campus, yes. But not employees. When I became disabled my repeat requests to have my job changed to something more functional for me and my team were ignored, my "confidential" meetings with HR were disclosed to my supervisor, who started harassing me about the weekly doctor appointments I required and the time I needed to be away for them, along with many other issues.

review_title: Staff work hard in a sometimes stressful but often gratifying environment
pros: If you're driven by a commitment to public service or enjoy the idea of contributing to research and academic knowledge attainment, this is a good place to be. Depending on the leadership of your School or department, you can exercise considerable autonomy. Lots of variety in projects and tasks. The campus is lovely.
cons:
Staff are lowest on the totem pole, beneath faculty, grad students and undergrads. Certain faculty and upper level administrators regard staff as interchangeable automatons or faceless paper shufflers. People often labor without recognition or appreciation of their efforts. 

The volume of work is enormous. Most employees perform the jobs of multiple people in the wake of retirements, layoffs, etc. 

There was a lack of guidance in professional development when I worked there, but it seems as though HR wants to improve this. It's up to the individual to investigate and seek formal training in new skills.  While supervisors support staff enrollment in voluntary training modules, staff often don't have time to attend due to work volume. 

Benefits are fair to good. Pay is below market value, but that is typical for staff positions in higher education. It's a trade-off employees must be willing to make if they want to contribute to the aims of the university.

review_title: Great transition job for UC Irvine newly graduated kids
pros: Great transition job for new UC Irvine graduates with a bachelors degree. The benefits package is on par with outside employers not more. The atmosphere isn't fast paced. The upper management is promoted from within so they've been there for a while. When I worked there, there were a fair amount of younger kids to converse with and hang out with so the environment was pretty good. If you need a quick opportunity after you graduate UC Irvine getting a job there shouldn't be too hard. It's very likely you know people working there that could refer and get you in quickly.
cons: Compared to the outside the pay is on the lower side. The upper management can get into hysterical moods sometimes asking for immediate actions. The technology we worked with is how you say "behind the curve". As is at many other State Universities. While the actual work was low stress, communicating the work and making internal changes was a headache. Dealing with everyday problems seemed like a big deal at times when they shouldn't. Probably because they were always stuck in their old ways. Most companies are reluctant to change so I guess I shouldn't blame them for something like that.

pros: they ask you to keep track of your time
cons: too many emails. But maybe that's like everywhere.

pros:
Interesting research
Effort to improve diversity
cons: Work/life balance depends on your lab

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Newport Beach, CA

cons: Demanding. Stressful. Management poor. Need more autonomy.

review_title: Golden opportunity to seriously impact the lives of new MBAs by teaching them how to conduct a job search.
job_title: Senior Associate Director in Irvine, CA
pros: University is truly a great place to work.  Lots of variety.  Lots of opportunities.  Generally intelligent (not brilliant) people.  Worthy of note:  benefits (actually quite generous) are tiered so those at the beginning of the pay scale get pretty much the same benefits as mainstream earners but their contributions are significantly less.
cons: Exec Dir. of  MBA Career Center is a total drama ... person.   And he's young so he'll be there a while.  Pretty much keeps to himself. Doesn't interact with staff.  Doesn't encourage excellence if it outshines him and uses statistics to manipulate standing of program.

pros:
Some driven staff members
Offers nice work opportunities for current students
cons:
Frequently dishonest about pay and compensation 
Director frequently "forgets" discussions on compensation 
Known perpetrators of abuse and predators in management positions

pros: I was happy with my compensation and benefits at UC, Irvine. There were tons of discounts and opportunities for staff to take advantage of both within UC and in our local community. I had an amazing direct supervisor who was very supportive of me. The name recognition of UC was also a plus professionally. UC, Irvine has an incredibly diverse student (and staff) population.
cons: There are many staff at UC, Irvine who have worked on campus their entire professional career. This meant that there are many leaders on campus who insist on processes being done 'they way it's always been done'. Many staff are not attune to the latest tech and are not open to new and innovative ideas. UC, Irvine also unfortunately has a regional reputation as not being a 'great' UC option in comparison to the rest of the system.  As a recruiter, I handled so many documents in hard-copy and with an incredibly archaic system  of hand filing paperwork in addition to scanning into a shared drive. You would think that such a huge institution would have moved to something faster and more up-to-date.

review_title: Great for Mechanical Engineering under Dr. Samuelsen!
pros:
I am in the department of Mechanical Engineering under Professor Samuelsen's lab. He manages his lab, consisting of roughly 40 graduate students, 10 undergraduate students, and 10 full time staff, amazingly. Because of it's large size, the lab functions almost like a family (not the dysfunctional kind), with Dr. Samuelsen as the patriarch. Funding is great -- reliably guaranteed by Dr. Samuelsen as long as he takes a liking to your attitude, work ethics, and talent (which is very likely, since you had to pass his interview and screening process to join the lab. Best decision of my life doing my Ph.D. under him.

Also, with a car, Irvine can be a really great city. The beach is nearby, which offers a great place to relax and, might I add, surf and sail.
cons: It is impossibly hard to do anything in the city of Irvine without a car, or without knowing anyone who has a car to take you to places.

review_title: Job security but lackluster work environment
job_title: Staff Research Associate III in Irvine, CA
pros: Job security, good health insurance options (albeit quite expensive for a PPO plan), visually-appealing campus.
cons: A lot of bureaucracy that impedes quick workflow for research teams. This is particularly the case with any construction/renovation projects or when trying to secure appropriate space to conduct funded research. The environment unfortunately feels a bit boring. There isn't a real feeling of pushing the envelope forward or striving to continuously improve (probably a by-product of being a publicly-funded institution with a bit too much job security...). I am also only speaking for the two departments of which I'm a part. Other schools/programs on campus may cultivate a different atmosphere, and most of my cons are likely department/school-dependent.

review_title: Ph.D. at the University of California Irvine (UCI)
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Irvine, CA
pros:
Location (sunny Southern California)
Decent infrastructure
Very good Health insurance plan
Very good Housing for Graduate students
The ARC - the sports and gym facilities are great
The Graduate Resource Center is amazing
Writing consultants are very thorough and effective
Great workshops on mentoring and communication
Libraries are very modern and interconnected to other external libraries. Librarians at UCI are extremely helpful and competent.
cons:
Finding a good professor to be your advisor can still be a hit and miss task.
I felt that some professors still have an old mentality of advising by threatening graduate students.

review_title: This is a great place to work for a busy college student looking for a job with flexible hours.
pros:
- They are very flexible with your hours. You set your own schedule based on your class schedule.
- Very friendly direct supervisors and coworkers
- Plenty of chances of moving up within the organization. 
- Located at the heart of campus, making your walk to class and work manageable.
cons:
- Upper level management does not communicate well with staff. They keep away and do not try to work with staff.
- Most of the time you bear the brunt of bad decisions of management. Customers will constantly complain about policies of the organization. 
- Compared with other organizations around campus, the pay is quite small. 
- You may be forced to work on holidays and during busy finals week.
- When your coworkers ask to take time off, you are left covering them. You work extremely long hours.

review_title: "Good place to work if you are a student looking for some extra cash"
job_title: Student Office Assistant in Irvine, CA
pros: I was a Student Office Assistant at one of the on-campus housing offices. All the staff were friendly and open to questions. Lots of downtime near the end of each quarter so you can get some work done for classes if there isn't a lot going on. Training is provided during the summer and you get to shadow current OAs, so you don't just start and expect to know what to do.
cons: Was a stressful experience at times, especially during the beginning of the school year and each quarter. If you're the only person at the front desk and 4-7 people come into the office at once all wanting different things, it's tough to manage everything and keep all the residents happy. Definitely don't be shy to ask for help if you need it.

review_title: Great opportunity to make a difference
job_title: Associate Director, MBA Career Center in Irvine, CA
pros: Students are wonderful to work with.  Job duties provide intrinsic opportunities to network and help both Orange County employers fill job openings and new grads locate great positions upon completing their MBAs.  National opportunities exist to lead national teams through MBACSC - the professional organization of career service workers across the country and throughout the world - and get recognized for your good work.  Can be a creative atmosphere to engage with other departments in the school if you are willing to reach out.  Job itself is very fulfilling and for a university, pay is not bad at all.
cons: Career Center leadership unresponsive & unsupportive.  No recognition for job well done.  While job itself is wonderful, atmosphere is acrimonious - too much micromanaging one day, and do whatever you want the next.  No information sharing or development of personnel.   Most associates like their job, but not the environment.

pros: The company culture is one that values work life balance and minimizes stress. Most of the people I worked under were very quick to make me feel like part of the OIT family, and day-to-day tasks are frequently mixed in with informal events like donuts in the coffee room or a group lunch break.
cons: Some of the technologies employed are not the most up to date or "bleeding edge" with in relation to other tech employers. Thus, if one wished to switch jobs in the future, it would be difficult.

review_title: Great Tutoring Experience for the Learning and Academic Resource Center
pros: The Tutor Advisors are easily accessible and do not have a significantly large age difference with the tutors; as long as you provide a great tutoring service, the LARC office is flexible with helping you as a tutor with whatever you need. You get evaluated randomly multiple times throughout the quarter, which is a little bit intimidating but also very helpful. You grow as a tutor as well as an individual person. You get to learn a lot of things about yourself, how to work with other people, and how to handle difficult situations.
cons: Hours are not flexible, especially as a student. The pay as a student is good but is significantly lower than tutoring individually on your own. There are a lot of other requirements in addition to tutoring such as bimonthly meetings, review sessions, giving evaluations of other tutors, and meeting with professors.

review_title: UCI needs to get up to speed with the times
pros: -The people are great, for the most part.
cons:
-I was forced to work as a contract employee for over 2 years and they would not give me a permanent position (as I live in Arizona).  My job can be done from anywhere and my boss supported me working remotely.  The upper administration, however, was against it despite UCI having a policy in place that allows for employees to work remotely.  I also received no pay increase for 2 years due to being a contract employee, yet they continued to renew my contract.
-The HR and hiring processes were unfair because of the above.  HR was generally unhelpful.
-The UCI IT team was unable to build a computer server for our group....for 2 years...due to having no support or resources.  Their IT systems and processes are archaic.

review_title: Stimulating Environment with a lot of possibilities to contact industry actors.
pros: Very nice environment, friendly community with a lot of contact with professors and other scientists. Nice facilities and a lot of very supportive administrative and technical staff in clean rooms and offices. You feel like a professor. If your project is well funded there is not big problems to buy material or equipments and to access the cleanroom. As other UC system colleges and because it's geographical location it is easy to drive to San Diego or UCLA to use their facilities for experimentation.
cons: In my case, working space had no windows. Although it was super very well equipped.

review_title: Sociology at UCI is an ambitious department; it's organized well and treats you well if you can play the game.
pros: Beautiful location, well funded department (no politics), very competent sociologists.
cons: The large size of the department leads to some degree of anonymity.  One is highly "encouraged" to focus solely on becoming R1 material.  Training and hiring good teaching is very undervalued.

job_title: Office Assistant Worked Full Time in Irvine, CA
pros: As described in the title, my supervisor, graduate staffs, professors are all very friendly.  School environment is great and peaceful.
cons:
I like working in a school environment, cos there's less office politics (given that my position had nothing to do with it.) However, imagine working in a large corporation, there're lots of bureaucratic issues.  Everything has to be done by the book, no exceptions.  Recommendation or suggestion of doing a job in a different way (with better outcome) will not be appreciated.  
Graduate students who are assistant professors are hard to track down when syllabus are due for printings.  Same situation applies to some of the professors.  I only know their names but never met them in person.

pros: Excellent environment, room for growth, promotes  from within. They are supportive, and truly want the employees to be happy.  Promotes learning and training.  They invest in their employees.  Collaborative. Work-life balance,  Excellent benefits and retirement. UC Irvine is an excellent employer and I am so very grateful for the opportunity!
cons: Sometimes working for a government agency, there is a lot of red tape, so it does take longer to get things done as far as approvals.  There is always a chain of command and the chain is long.  We do run a little lean at times and getting approval for additional headcount can sometimes be challenging. Also, the pay is lower than the industry standard in some areas.

review_title: Research the job market before joining a graduate program
pros:
Top notch faculty, excellent  research 
Supportive work environment
cons:
Running the UC system like a business is beginning to have an effect on the quality of the institution. They're all about the numbers- taking on more and more undergrads each year without adequate infrastructure to handle them. Graduate student enrollment has also increased, and in the shrinking academic job market, this does not bode well for life post grad school. No one will mention this to you as a graduate student.
The cost of on-campus housing for graduate students ranges from the bad to absurd. Rents are raised every year and most students that live on campus pay 40-70% of their salary towards housing.

pros: Supportive of continuing education and personal development. Access to a variety of cultural activities and events.  Working with college students keeps you up to date and young.
cons: Very political.  It is certainly not what you know, but who you know that gets you ahead at UCI.  The poor performing employees are moved around instead of being fired.  The distribution of funds is unequal so some departments have extreme excess while others barely get by.

pros: If you like working with students and on a college campus it's a good place to be.  They do give very generous vacation and sick days.  I also get many holidays off that businesses typically don't give.  The campus is pretty.  In my position I get a lot of freedom to determine how I do my job.
cons: You will never get a raise no matter how well you perform.  There are limited opportunities for upward mobility.  Parking is very expensive--$50 per month for general parking

review_title: Great university in a beautiful area, satisfaction depends partially on the department.
pros: Solid place with benefits and pension. It is also an established and well developed hr program with training and development to help anyone move forward. Also, if a specific job at the university does not work out, there are many departments on campus that may work better.
cons: It is reliant on state budgets and tuition. The state has had some hard times and as a result there always exists the chance of budget cuts affection specific departments. There are also some who work there who are just waiting to retire and are not motivated to develop or grow, their lack of motivation can become contagious.

pros: UC Irvine offers fairly decent benefits. Staff development and training opportunities are available. Working in an environment of innovation and research is exciting. Working with under-grad and graduate students is rewarding.
cons: Many Managers and HR appear not there to support you, but to protect UCI and their favorite staff employees and cliques. The new review process is unfair and leans autocratic. There is no cost of living increases now and salary increases are at the whim of Manager's discretion. To increase salary one must shift job positions and departments every couple of years. An unfortunate disadvantage, especially if you like your current job.

job_title: Assistant Project Scientist in Irvine, CA
pros: Kind of safe for whom want to do some academic researches as long as you have secured funding
cons:
For non-tenure track academic researchers, the secured funding become harder and harder to see/have, as long as your boss say "we are out of fund", the researches is really out of fun!
You will also see some incapable administration staffs doing something nonsense everyday but have much higher salary than you!

review_title: Great work / life balance, benefits and stability
pros: Best environment I've ever worked in. The university makes sure that employees are treated fairly and respectfully. There is an entire infrastructure to support and foster those principles. Being that the UC system is so large, there are many opportunities to advance or make changes. Benefits are incredibly generous and vacation, sick time and paid holidays are plenfiful.
cons: Because of the stability and difficulty with firing under performers, there can be a tendency for complacent attitudes. People who embrace change and emerging technology will find themselves with challenges.

pros: Good colleagues, supportive PIs overall, decent benefits thanks to constant negotiations between the labor union and the UC system. Surrounded by hubs for biotech, pharma, and medical device companies. Excellent location to network and job hunt.
cons: No visa support beyond J for international postdocs in most cases, some rumors of abusive PIs, typical fare in academic research institutions. If you have a decent PI, what you get out of your postdoc is mainly dependent on how wisely you spend your time/effort on your own goals.

pros:
1. Great location. Irvine is one of the best places I have lived. The campus is close to the beach and many other place of attractions. 
2. Work environment. Really depends on department and the lab you work in. The lab I worked in happened to be a very friendly environment
3. Benefit. UC Irvine postdocs take advantages of having an union. The union-negotiated benefit packages are superior to many other institutions including private companies. Best medical plan I have ever had.
cons:
Lay-back life style
Inefficiencies in administrations (again this depends on department)
Administrative staffs are not quite enhusiatic of what they do and tend to be low in work efficiency.
Administrative staffs pay little attention to postdocs. To get things done, sometimes it is necessary to get your senior advisor involved.

review_title: Allowed room for growth and opportunities
pros: With a large employee pool to trade shifts, this part time job was very flexible for a full time student like myself.  If you care about the job, its very easy to promote and have a large amount of responsibility and gain tons of experience.  Lots of hours available and the most amazing people I have ever met- nice, respectful, family like environment.
cons: Under new management and things are headed downhill.  They receive money from tuition (being a school entity) and serving students free, however they are in it for the profit from renting clients and in my opinion give little back to the campus unity given that they are the "student center"

review_title: A positive working experience that I would recommend to anyone with a strong grasp of the course being taught.
pros: Teaching Assistantships cover tuition for that quarter and give a stipend that should cover general living expenses for the quarter.  The pay rate is rather high for a part time job.  The job can be very rewarding when you see students grasp the material well.
cons: TA positions have high variability, depending on the professor, students, department, etc., so there is no guarantee that the experience will be enjoyable.  There could be many assignments to grade and larger/lower-division classes will be more difficult to manage.

review_title: Worked as teaching assistant in economics and social science courses.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Irvine, CA
pros: The time and energy that is required is quite low. To be a good teaching assistant, I needed to merely meet the requirements from my contract; most TAs don't even do that and there are no repercussions.
cons:
There is a high variance when it comes to which professor you end up working with. Some have high expectations and give quite a bit of guidance; others will give you free rein in your sections and scantron exams to grade.
The worst aspect is the matching process between TAs and professors. The system is strange.

pros: Some of the smaller classes in certain subjects can be great to TA for, because the students are motivated, and it's material that you're also studying so you know you're a competent resource for the students. Much of the grading/lesson planning/preparation can be done on your own time.
cons: Some professors are a nightmare to be a TA for - they're impossible to contact, and don't communicate with you regarding their expectations of you as a TA. You may also be assigned to TA a class on a topic you know nothing about, and this is miserable for both you and the students you're supposed to be teaching.

review_title: Great job for students... as long as they don't go through budget cuts.
pros: It was fast, easy, and painless getting a job at UC Irvine as a student. Working with your peers on a daily basis is great for networking and gaining a feel for the environment. Since most of the other workers are students also, you can all relate and get advice from older peers.
cons: Job availability goes down as fee hikes go up. This past year hasn't been great for the economy in California and the UC systems reflected that. I know that several departments downsized especially with the libraries and many students "voluntarily left" due to shortened hours.

pros: Everyone is very close, supportive and work well together. There is an obvious commitment to student success, improving the program and maintaining curriculum standards. Working with students from so many countries is amazing. Schedules are flexible for teachers and students. Student Learning Objectives are clearly outlined.
cons: Sometimes there is a resistance to change whether for a textbook, curriculum component or classroom technology. This industry goes through ups and downs so employment can be unstable. As with most teaching position, you can find yourself spending a lot of time on preparation or other unpaid assignments.

review_title: No raises and long working conditions
pros: If you enjoy working with infants and toddlers and are a soon to be parent, the skills learned here will be helpful to raising your own child.
cons: There was a lot of diaper changing, dish washing, and laundry work. You don't get to interact and play with kids as much as you are doing chores. When I originally signed up for the position I thought I was going to interact with kids a lot more, and I do get that opportunity here but not as much. There are no raises here whatsoever, even for part time employees that have been around for 4 years.  You can probably find a better job for better pay with raises with a restaurant on UC Irvine campus.

pros: UCI has great overall benefits. It's almost impossible to be fired unless you commit an egregious act. Great retirement system. Lots of campus interaction.
cons: Unless you are in a newly created department or your department is aging with a lot of upper level employees looking at retirement, you will not be able to improve your pay or position. Pay is not great compared to private employment; UCI does not provide enough of an incentive for standard workers to obtain a campus position unless one wants to work for a non-profit or is interested in giving back to the community or is .

pros: Right on campus so it is convenient for students who want to work and go to school at the same time. Ok pay for the work you do.
cons: The lines are long. Training could be provided or more experience learned before being thrown out to start making sandwiches. When people are standing in line and the line is long, it can get a bit hectic. Learning the subs and sanwiches on the first day without any experience and a big line is kinda difficult.

review_title: Worked as a teaching assistant and course coordinator while being a graduate student
pros: Most of the professors are very friendly, they really help you to improve your skills. I enjoyed being able to teach such a wide variety of courses including field, lab and discussions.
cons: Some classes put a lot of grading on the TAs and it will take more than the alotted 20hrs per week that you get paid for. They also will not tell you what class you will be teaching till after you have signed the contract agreeing to teach that quarter.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Irvine, CA
pros: It is a fairly high energy environment and there are many workshops, classes and presentations to sit in on if you have the time and interest. Also plenty of resources available.
cons: Bureaucracy at the university level works very slowly, have waited over 2 months for some paperwork now. They also have some policies regarding purchasing equipment that lead to slow process times and raise prices for the groups buying. Department level can be faster depending on the nature of the work and what section of the department is involved.

pros: Nice campus with growing walk-on facilities for students and researchers. Some extremely smart and ambitious faculty who are excited to collaborate.
cons: Insulatory environment for students. Within the sciences, some professors are extremely out of touch with what their students are doing in the lab and research setting. Not enough inclusion of senior, non-faculty researchers in departmental decisions or programs.

pros: I'm a graduate student here and right now I'm working as a research assistant. UC Irvine has good environment, good professors and great opportunities for all academic areas. Multicultural atmosphere makes you feel welcome all the time.
cons: Living expense is really high. If you are not living on campus, half of your salary will go for the rent. Irvine is more like a outskirt rather than a modern city (even though is pretty new and well constructed), there is limited entertainment event and all you want to do is your research project.

review_title: Work on the art of education
pros: You're surrounded by good faculty and  students who have a lot of potential.
cons: There's little priority given to actual teaching, and the materials and time necessary to do it.  Senior management is disconnected from, or doesn't care about, the needs of faculty and students.  It's a huge university, and a huge bureaucracy, and no steps seem to be underway to make the bureaucracy less paralyzing.  Funding cuts are not only chronic, but arbitrary.  As a result, the air of cynicism and disappointment is profound.

pros: Some of the Principal Investigators(PI) in UCI are very good. If you work in these labs, you could gain experience, training, motivation and even assistance to build your own career.
cons: Some P.I s are very stupid and below standards! My advise is to attend their class or ask them questions to evaluate if the PI is competent before joining the lab.

review_title: Decent pay for actually 51% time, PhD track in engineering
pros: Enough to live in most places in the area because rent is not too expensive, health insurance is provided if your prof is paying your stipend
cons: How hard you have to work depends on your prof (generally, pretty hard because you have maybe at least two projects)... student health center sucks--none of my health problems got resolved

pros: Top-ranked medical center, relatively new buildings, some great staff, highly competitive pay, great medical and retirement benefits, nurses represented by a union
cons:
Management is unfair and doesn't seem to care about employees. There's a lot of favoritism toward certain staff members. I was a loyal employee for several years but felt unappreciated. 

Resources not available to employees. I had to buy my own pens and post-it notes, and drinking straws for patients because per management those items could not be provided by UCI due to budget constraints. 

Career growth was stifled, not encouraged.

pros: The work is a lot of fun, it is really rewarding when you help students learn.  You also make great friends while tutoring.  This job is great for someone who wants to be a grad student because it will give hands-on experience teaching (like a TA).
cons: You have to put in a lot of hours if you want to do a good job.  You need to free up a lot of time in your schedule if you want to tutor at LARC.  Also, often times you spend more time preparing for your tutorials then what you get paid for.

pros: It is a really easy job. Very flexible hours because they work around your schedule. You do learn about customer service and how to handle specific situations. Able to do homework at times, depending on the shift that you get. Able to take shifts or give-up shifts, which is really helpful because other jobs do offer something like this. Managers are easy to get a long with as long as you do not do anything bad, but that is how it goes at every job.
cons: Sometimes you do not get the amount of hours that you want and sometimes you get shifts that you do not like.

job_title: Senior Collections Representative in Orange, CA
pros: They have great benefits, great location in Orange.  Doing a job which I enjoy, medical billing.  Work full time and nice time of 8am to 5pm.  Very nice work environment .
cons: There is a good possibility going to be laid off.  There are changing the way they do billing.  Any departments will be moving to the centralized billing.  I work for a department outside this department.

job_title: Stacks Assistant II in Irvine, CA
pros: This is a really easy job.  It has a very flexible schedule where you can come in and leave whenever you want.  You round your hours to the nearest 0.5 hours.  You get a raise every year you work (although, it is a very small raise)
cons: Some days you will have very few books, so your hours are limited by the amount of workload you have to do.  Training is done in one day for 3 hours where the boss gives you games to play (which is fun)

review_title: Can't beat on-campus jobs in terms of convenience
job_title: Library Security Monitor in Irvine, CA
pros:
-Very good pay for a student
-Supervisor conforms work shifts around your schedule
-Can study while on the job
cons:
-All hours are closing shifts, therefore late-night shifts (think 9PM-11PM or 11PM-3AM)
-Some shifts are extremely short (the aforementioned 9PM-11PM is only 2 hours long)
-Libraries are open 24/7 during 10th and Finals Week, so the shifts extend to those periods (3AM-7AM)
-Libraries also smell because of unhygienic students

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Irvine, CA
pros: Lots of learning opportunities with fantastic teachers and researchers in synthetic organic chemistry. Exceptional graduate classes and a supportive environment. The research environment is strengthened by the quality of graduate students and post-docs
cons: There is very little to find fault with at UC Irvine. The workload in a typical first year of graduate school can be overwhelming when taken with teaching but it makes you stronger to get through.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Irvine, CA
pros: Good health insurance (dental included)
cons: The salary is low compared to the cost of living for the area

pros:
Middle Management was great, understanding, and actually cared. Felt like she was in the trenches along with everyone else.

Also, working for a non-profit gives your a sense of pride and accomplishment that is seldom found in other places. 
Calling Alumni was not menial and helped by the attitudes of everyone around you. Atmosphere was fun and exciting.
cons:
Some of the downsides were that even in a non-profit, upper management only cared about the bottom line even at the risk of alienating the alumni base.

That and they killed the program after we could not make a number.

review_title: Very good and modern facilities, campus and neighborhood
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Irvine, CA
pros: I am at the EECS department. It is very dynamic and has many good professors on its list. You have access to many educational and world-class recreational resources.
cons: The students (especially, undergraduates) need to be more selectively admitted. Curricula need to be more rigorous. I am coming from a developing country and I can tell you for sure I learnt much more and was more productive in my home country.

review_title: Working a Job on a University Campus
pros: Convenient if attending UCI classes; my work schedule was made to fit around my class schedule; all workers were UCI students like me, and most customers were students/faculty, lending to a nicer atmosphere; upward mobility still possible, workers could become managers
cons: You can only work as long as you're a full-time UCI student (or part-time? Either way, if you're not enrolled, you can't work); some things such as transitions and communication, esp. for covering shifts, need improvement

review_title: Secure jobs but with flaws like anywhere else
pros:
Benefits- Medical, Dental, Vision, Retirement (100% medical benefits and 80% of your salary at 20 years, 5-year vestment).
Job security and mobility- it is easy to change jobs within campus because a continuing employee is always preferred.
Training opportunities (not always the best quality, but it is at least available to you).
Depending on what department you work in, it can be family-friendly as far as flexibility.
Sense of community within the campus; campus partnering for events (depending on where you work).  Some appreciation meals & events for staff.
cons:
It is very expensive to park here (regular parking is around $64/month, preferred which gets you to the front spaces and/or bottom floors is $80+)
Upper management hiring practices inherently flawed and unfair; if you know the right person, you will get the job regardless of your aptitude, leaving many offices with poor management.  I have had several jobs on campus and every boss I have had I would rate as unsatisfactory.  However, I have enjoyed the content of my jobs.
The University as a whole works very, very, very slowly; nothing ever gets done quickly.
Pay- lower than other companies with the inability to move up within your department, so the only way to make more money is to change positions.  No merit increases.  This discourages department loyalty, and loyalty to the University.
Internal job postings- inherently discourages job competition; these jobs are only available to current employees.  However, if more than 1 person within an office wants to apply, this creates an uncomfortable dynamic and most simply don't apply so as not to step on toes.  I feel this creates a flawed hiring system because the upper hand always goes to upper management (in decision-making and in applicant pool).
Management gets away with a lot; I'm not sure why, but they do.  The appropriate eyes and ears are not turned toward this issue.
Funding issues (dependent on department), affecting office functions, growth opportunities & development, programming, hiring of professional and student staff.

review_title: A great place to be a grad student as long as you avoid the bureaucracy
job_title: NSF Graduate Research Fellow in Irvine, CA
pros: A great quality education but much chiller than MIT, Cal-tech, or Berkeley.  Also, Irvine is a great place to live.
cons: Lots of bureaucracy and fees. If you want something done you have to go to four different offices and send a dozen emails. It will take months.

pros: Very warm, friendly environment for student workers.  They understand that we need time off to study for finals and midterms and that sometimes we just need a day off to relax.
cons: Sometimes boring with nothing to do and no real room to grow as a student worker because we aren't "full time" workers.  Likewise, no benefits.

pros: Really fun group of people to work with and fun job overall. The supervisors are great and even the director is a really cool guy. I would recommend anyone who is into sports to work as a referee here.
cons: It can get kind of stressful if you take the job too seriously. It does have a small learning curve that will take time to adjust to. If you can't handle taking criticism and talking towards an angry crowd then maybe this isn't the right job for you.

pros: Fantastic work environment, outstanding coworkers, competitive sakary, amazing benefits, lots of flexibility, lots of room for growth, and a sense of pride about what you do.
cons: Can be subject to budget issues/dependent on the State budget. It can also take a long time to get an interview/land a job. (HUGE pro tip: if you are just getting your foot in the door, apply through the temp pool. You will get placed MUCH faster - it's a great way to get your foot in the door.)

review_title: A fairly laid back environment. Minimal pressure to rush tasks. Emphasis on research.
pros: Students were often passionate and participated. Bonding between graduate students. Great location - just miles away from multiple world renowned beaches. Weather is perfect. Very clean, nice safe area. Beautiful weather. Top tier research school.
cons: Tension between professors. Constant construction (this should be a plus for the future) was disruptive. Limited parking in certain locations.

pros: You gain real-life experience mentoring students in your field of expertise and build organizational and communication skills.  This is also a good networking position as much of the planning and testing done in groups with fellow graduate students.
cons: Grading can be time-consuming.  This work does require about four hours of standing without breaks, so is not for people with contraindications.

review_title: Four years of research assistance experiences
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Irvine, CA
pros:
Free Parking if you live next to the campus (up to 45 times per year).
Freedom of research and good advices from the advisor.
Many knowledgeable and experienced professors in the campus and their classes are very helpful for doing research.
cons:
Long work hours. 
Have to learn how to say no, otherwise you won't be able to sleep if the research scientist or postdoc love to work whole night. 
Summer salary is good but the enforcement of retirement deposit can be up to 25%. It's way too over!

pros: Being a teaching assistant while attending graduate school give you a small salary in addition to paying for all of your tuition and fees,
cons: Work condition vary drastically with assignments, some students end up working full time hours when the time commitment is supposed to be a maximum of twenty. Summer employment is unreliable.

review_title: Work in Student Life & Activities in the Division of Continuing Education
pros: You get paid to go on trips to big attractions like Disneyland, Universal Studios, Las Vegas, etc. Meeting international students and teaching them about American culture is already rewarding in itself if you enjoy socializing and expanding your network. You can also sign up for your own shifts so you're in control of how much you work.
cons: Sometimes hard to work during the actual weekday because shifts were sparse. My school schedule at the time didn't match well with the shifts I wanted to work during the weekday.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Irvine, CA
pros: It is very fun interacting with all the students. It is great especially when you realize how much you are affecting other people's lives.
cons: Little pay compared to the amount of work done. No promotions or salary increase. Sometimes it gets hectic with all the work that is piling up.

review_title: Fantastic on-campus job for computer-savvy students
job_title: Senior Residential Network Consultant in Irvine, CA
pros:
ResNet is a fantastic place to gain work experience in an IT-related field. The office is situated right in the Student Center of UCI, which is a prime location on campus.
The majority of people you will work with are students as well and they are all very enjoyable to work with, especially if you're well-versed in reddit. As a new-hire, everyone is very helpful in helping you learn how to fix the most common issues that come up. There's lots of opportunity to improve your customer service skills as well, as you will be constantly troubleshooting with (sometimes unhappy) residents and their internet/cable TV issues. The pro-staff are some of the best to work with on campus - helpful, knowledgeable, personable, and overall really awesome people. The different issues you troubleshoot can teach you some pretty interesting things about networking and computers. Though some can be more frustrating than others, most issues can be solved very quickly and the solutions are easy to pick up.
Hours are extremely flexible. Expect an average of 10-15 hours a week on average, but it's very easy to work more or less depending on your availability. The pay starts out average but increases regularly over time, and in very generous increments - the pay can be very handsome after only a year of working, and if you work enough to be promoted to senior, you'll get into the territory of some of the highest student wages on campus.
Overall a great way to get some experience in IT/networking/software, or even just a solid on-campus job that pays well, is convenient to go to, and has very flexible hours.
cons: Though some issues were interesting to troubleshoot, some were extremely frustrating and could take several hours to fix. Though rare, these issues did come up and can be taxing. The core of the position is  troubleshooting issues on a very antiquated system (I'm looking at you, Cisco NAC) and it's still, to this day, difficult for me to understand why such a system exists on a campus where better solutions exist (open WiFI with no frills to get online). Lots and lots of down time - this was a pro for me, but to some it may be a con. Angry residents - though these cases are rare, they happen. If you think customers can overreact at restaurants over mistakes in their food, imagine how people can be without internet access, with the added layer of protection from email or phone call to voice their anger. None of these points would deter me from working here though - If I were to do it all over again I would.

review_title: Job security, good benefits, rigid organization so inefficient internal processes
pros:
* Teaching and working with undergraduates and graduate students.  Making a difference in young person's life.
* Intellectually brilliant professors that one works with as colleagues and mentors.
* Autonomy in and ability to pursue your own research interests. 
* Flexibility of work schedule, you define your own hours and how to utilize it.  You don't have 9-5 corporate grind, yet  (see below) 60-70 hour work week regular for professor or graduate student.
* Summer months off because you're working on the academic calendar, although professors can teach summer school and earn additional income.
cons:
* poor morale among professors and graduate students in humanities division.  a thin layer of depression settled over the faculty, graduate students because of shrinking resources and drastic cuts in state financial support.  This in all honestly is the nature of modern academic life in the humanities  for a PhD graduate student or tenured professor.  Technology, the new profit-oriented business model imposed on university schema is greatly changing the traditional profession of a humanities professor.  Economics, CS, science, law have more practical world justification for continued robust financial support of their programs.  Unfair, but where the trend is, and I find it difficult to see the trend changing for the better while keeping things same way for humanities.
* 60-70 hour work week typical for professor and graduate student positions in humanities, to fulfill functions in teaching, academic research, being an adviser to students, professional service as administrator, attend professional social functions, strongly advises by management to support professional advancement in the department.  So your work week can easily extend to Saturday and evenings.
* little opportunity for professional advancement for administrative staff working in departmental office.  if you want to be promoted, you have to wait for someone to leave or retire, which happens rarely because a university job is so stable, so often you'll have to move to a different department if you want a higher job position.

pros: Informatics department abundantly rewards its students with teaching assistantship and research assistantship. Almost all the informatics students get TA. While it is rare to get a teaching assistantship in the first quarter, it is fairly easy in the subsequent ones.
cons: Some professors just don't like to take responsibility for their courses. Certain professors are not as progressive and open minded as the other ones. Some professors are really cool but the ones whose courses are not well organized feel like a disaster to work for. Also, TA is better than a reader even in heavy workload.

pros: This place is great if you want to get your first experiences as a referee. They give you all the rules for each sport you want to teach, but make sure you pick it up quickly because 2 weeks of practice doesn't make you faster at calling the games when its done in real time
cons: The amount of training is limited due to the school schedule and the rudeness and yelling from the players does not help. All and all, the yelling is more to let the frustration out and pressure you to actual do your job

job_title: Senior Pharm Tech in Orange, CA
pros: it was a great Job, worked with great folk, most of the time, very fast pace, work is fairly simple to do and very repetitive.
cons: High level of stress, and no advancement for technologists, if you like to do the same thing forever this will work for you. Most stay for the money and that is the quality of workers there, others like myself leave for better opportunities, retired after 25 years of service. Teaching the field now, love it cause i am appreciated for my hard work.

review_title: Great Location, Great People, Great Place to Work
job_title: Manager of Video Production Services in Irvine, CA
pros: Working for a UC System School is beyond rewarding. The benefits are amazing, most people enjoy their job which makes the work environment positive. The location of Irvine is great! Plus generous vacation and sick time.
cons: The only downside to a UC System is that pay isn't always up to par with what your industry might be paying, but the benefits help outway this factor.

pros: A lot of services available for staff wellness. The benefits are great!
cons: Even though the institution touts innovation, it's really just a marketing term. As far as innovation occurring in the workplace it is seriously lacking. Beware of an excessive amount of political posturing on the job. Most decisions are made politically rather then what will help the university or make things more efficient,

review_title: Overworked, but it's in a good environment
pros: The students and your colleagues are all very good.  The benefits are also quite good. And of course you get a PhD or Masters while you're at it (and the quality of education is quite high).
cons: The pay is horrendously low for the area, class sizes continue growing, and you're heavily encouraged to put in more hours than allowed by your contract.  Management refuses to negotiate in good faith and engages in intimidation tactics.

pros: Two great bosses who were supportive and helpful; did what they could to mitigate the crazy budget cuts; helpful new Dean who genuinely cares.  Vast majority of the staff were helpful and easy to deal with.
cons: The across-the-board budget cuts (weren't the UC's fault, but still weren't fun); at times the office culture could be a bit rough; as an academic, forget about work-life balance.  It just doesn't exist.

review_title: An opportunity to grow and learn applicable functions of my future endeavors
pros:
Good pay for an on campus job.
Works with your class/school schedule.
Multiple tiers within the workplace to move upwards.
cons: Poor effort on some fronts by supervisors to maintain a healthy and effective work place.

review_title: UC Irvine is a stable employer, most of the time it's a nice place to work, and Irvine is a very place to live
pros: UC Irvine is a stable employer, most of the time it's a nice place to work, and Irvine is a very place to live
cons: Low pay, only part time. Irvine is very expensive, so research assistant can hardly support oneself. And the job is only temperary

review_title: great place to live and work
pros: postdocs all work extremely long hours. But at least here we work crazy hours in a beautiful place with plenty of sunshine. People who work here are generally happy, and its not uncommon for people to take breaks in the day before going back to lab.  There are more ties to industry here and people make constructive networking efforts for non-academic jobs.
cons: Not a high track record of success in terms of number of postdocs who go on to attain research-intensive faculty positions.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Irvine, CA
pros: Great weather and beautiful campus. Some of the professors actually try to help.
cons: In my time at UCI, I witnessed several cases of unethical misconduct by faculty and staff as well as fraud in the laboratories by the PI.

job_title: IT Support Technician in Irvine, CA
pros: Great people, great location. The people there work hard for newer methods of research. They care for what they work on.
cons: The location is on the property of UC Irvine. Parking here can be painful as UCI parking always gets you if you forget your parking pass or park in the wrong spot.

pros:
Very fun environment very friendly customers.  great training, great pay.  managers are helpful.
great reputation.  room for growth and opportunity for advancement
cons: too much pressure to work over time.  too many politics among upper management.  always work on holidays.  not recognized for work well done.

review_title: Great place to work if you need help paying for tuition.
pros:
-It was always convenient to stop by in between classes
-A lot of your pay check is exempt from certain taxes because of your position in the educational field and you get more of your taxes back at the end of the year because of your status as a student
-High potential of working with friends or classmates
cons:
-Maximum Hours enforced for student workers
-No job security after graduation in order to make room for current students to take your position

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher (Physics) in Irvine, CA
pros: UC Irvine is a good research university for the sciences. There are plenty of opportunities to collaborate. I personally worked in the Physics department and had collaborations in the Chemistry department. If you are going for Physics definitely check out the ChAMP program, which is available for Chemistry, Engineering, and Physics students. Also, the campus is beautiful, the weather is great, and there are beaches, mountains, and city life (LA) nearby.
cons: I can't think of a good con. Overall, I had a great experience.

pros: They have a great online training program used to teach and motivate individuals into the work safety environment. Great staff and HR.
cons:
I wish there were more opportunity for students and to be able to manage time. 
You need to buy a personal parking pass, employers must buy their aprking pass.
Parking enforcement is strong and not lenient on tickets.

job_title: OpenCourseWare Student Assistant in Torrance, CA
pros: Flexible hours, friendly work environment, air-conditioned offices, diversity in work, mostly laid back deadlines, encouraging boss, entry work experience, great coworkers. Also there are plenty of company events to look forward to monthly.
cons: Technical errors every now and again, uncomfortable kitchen occurrences, spontaneous deadlines, too easy work that can be completed within a short time.

job_title: Post Doctoral Scholar in Irvine, CA
pros:
California postdocs are unionized, so we get better pay that the rest of the US.
All the pros of being a postdoc? I won't get into that here. It will always depend on your PI you get hired by.
cons:
Housing costs around UCI are ridiculous. Living on your own around here will be VERY tight on your salary, even with the unionized wages.

If you don't mind a roommate while being a so-called professional with a Ph D then it isn't so bad...

pros: The weather at Irvine is excellent. The online library in UCI, specific to chemistry literature, is excellent. The facilities (NMR, MS) are great!
cons: I had to teach too much. Most professors don't care too much about career development of graduate student. The registration office of UCI is horrible.

review_title: This is a positive, energetic, rewarding place to work
pros: It is rewarding to be a part of the process that takes incoming students, provides them with knowledge and learning experiences, and then sends them out into the world to lead the next generation.
cons: As with any government job, this is a large bureaucracy and the salaries are limited when compared to private companies.

review_title: Great work if you don't have a car to get off campus
pros: If you live on campus, it's a great way to make money between classes. Even though you get paid just over minimum wage at best, they work with your class schedule, never forcing you to miss out on what you are paying for.
cons: The wages are probably the only downside, that and, for most of the jobs, there are limitations on how many hours you are allowed to work per week.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Irvine, CA
pros: Fellow students are friendly, easy-going, and not as depressed as grad students at other schools I have visited.  The campus is attractive, and there are many options for food and grocery shopping within walking distance.
cons: It can be difficult to be a poor graduate student in such a wealthy area.  UCI also lacks the university centered culture of many college towns, and there are limited options in the local area for students to go out and play.

pros: Great place to work. Lots of benefits, the graduate student union is amazing, and the services provided by the campus are great. HR is very on top of everything
cons: There were occasional issues with the janitorial staff not cleaning when they said they had. We had visibly dirty floors in our building with trash that could sit around for more than a week.

review_title: No room for growth, chaotic leadership and lack of useful skills
pros:
-Relaxing environment (1 hour of real work a day)
-Good benefits and holidays
cons:
-No training, they do not invest in their employees
-toxic environment, lots of petty drama due to bored employees
-no motivation or morale, everyone is there to collect their government paycheck and sit at their desks like vegetables.
-leadership is scatter brained and likes to keep things from staff
-no meaningful work, they do not like people who move to fast or take initiative

pros: The students are, by and large, earnest and hard-working. I really loved the ethnic diversity of the student body (primarily Asian-American).
cons: No convenient office space for lecturers or TAs, growing enrollments, lack of organized teaching resources in some departments and programs.

review_title: Only a good place for grad school if you are independently wealthy
pros:
Respectable faculty in most departments
Beautiful and safe place to live
cons:
Absolutely atrocious at enforcing Tilte IX violations the OEOD is a joke, it is set up to protect the University not the students
Not enough housing for grad students (even if they promise you housing)
Terrible policies related to maternity leave for grad students

review_title: Don't know anything else, just a graduate student
pros: Irvine is surrounded by a nice area and many companies with job opportunities. The surrounding area is diverse and so are experiences and food.
cons: The campus is quite busy since many students commute so parking gets filled up and they repeatedly try to change things up such as zoning. This only affects students.

pros:
Flexible hours
Relatively easy job compared to other campus jobs
My boss was very nice and understanding of my situations
The people who works there are all very nice
cons: This job does not pay well compared to other campus jobs, no promotion or bump in salary what so ever. I have received the same salary for the 3 years I worked here.

pros: I love UC Irvine because of the great balance of work and home life. When you get off of work, you're off, there are no stresses for the following day and no calls being made to your cell phone.
cons: Being that UC Irvine is such a large campus, it can be hard to get to know people outside of your department. It can also be a bit quiet based on the number of people in each department.

pros: Working for a leading institution that every one knows and respects is a great position to be as a recruiter and counselor. There is true team work going on and people are passionate about their work.
cons: Sometimes there is too much paperwork to be done and processes that come with a large organization. Overall there are no major issues working here.

pros:
-Nice area to live
-Good weather with little issue in traveling
-Good benefits in terms of medical and dental
-Time off is plentiful
-Nice savings account with credit union
cons:
-Entrenched Bureaucracy
-Needless Paperwork
-Management is not concerned with concerns of employees
-Inefficient processes in place to process and execute requests from facility management upgrades to reimbursements

pros: The environment provided here is second to none. The entire faculty is very warm and inviting. I would recommend any work here.
cons: There are absolutely zero downsides. The weather is top notch. The pay scale is amazing. Words can't describe how excited I am to be working here.

review_title: Graduate Student Research at UC Irvine
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Irvine, CA
pros: Financial support has always been available as a graduate student at UC Irvine. Work load has been very reasonable, but this varies from professor to professor.
cons: No real downsides to being a graduate student researcher at UC Irvine in general. Downsides will depend on your specific case.

review_title: Very supportive environment for undergrad student workers
pros:
Full-time staff go out of their way to make sure schedule works for students
Friendly environment that supports undergraduate lifestyle
Little perks like goodie bags during holidays and coffee and donuts during meetings
cons:
If you fall behind, no one really notices until it's too late
Full-time staff are overworked and underpaid
Students have different levels of commitment and availability, so can be difficult to manage at times

review_title: Good research experience at UC Irvine
pros: The working environment is very good. Most of the time, your boss is very nice, and even provide helpful advice on your work. Maintaining a good relationship with workmates is also fairly easy.
cons: Sometimes, it is hard for you to find a time to meet with your boss to discuss your progress, and get advice from them. The life might be somewhat boring since there is not much entertainment around the campus.

review_title: Join UCI if you have no other option
pros: Southern California is beautiful and there are a lot of companies around in the area for better student placement.
cons: Most professors run their lab in complete anarchy. I am sure there are some good professors, but the university in general is  a very hostile place for graduate students and post-docs. Also the bureaucracy is sickening. I cannot comment about undergraduate education.

pros: A lot of learning is on the way. Professor are very approachable, very nice campus, housing secure, good enough health insurance
cons: A lot of test to take, but so is at any other school, I think. There is not a lot to see on campus when you want to do something different than work

pros: Nice location, pretty low-key day to day.

review_title: Very beneficial for developing customer service experience.

cons: Weekend shifts can get boring. Sometimes things are a bit disorganized. Due to budget cuts, with a smaller workforce, it can be harder to recieve coverage.

pros: Flexible times, challenging and exiting working environment with many possibilities of good collaborations varying roles and focusing on different aspects o scientific research. Good  employee relationships.
cons: The salary is too low to live in south California. The city of Irvine is quite boring without any opportunity to have a good social and cultural life and it makes the work/life relation unbalanced.

pros: Relaxed work conditions. Work load is balanced over a 8am to 5pm work day. The university promotes employee safety and safe working conditions.
cons: Sometimes work can be difficult. There might be long days depending on what kind of work is being done. For example, my specialty is histology, and may require working overtime and on the weekends if necessary.

review_title: Best work-study experience at UCI Career Center
job_title: Student Resource Assistant in Irvine, CA
pros:
Counselors who really care for your future
Get to learn all the ins and outs of career searching after college
Warm environment
cons:
It can get a little slow sometimes but that just depends on if a lot of students visit the center or not.
There's definitely something to do all the time though, you just have to find it.
Not many cons I can think of.

review_title: Research Specialist at University California Irvine.
pros:
Great place for research, lots of hard working, like minded people all working hard to make a difference in their field. 
Friendly community on a beautiful campus.
Access to great amenities of the campus. 
All kinds of social gatherings are organized.
cons: It is not really a con of the work itself, however, renting a house close to work around Irvine can be very expensive.

review_title: Good place to go be a Grad Employee
pros: The healthcare benefits for graduate students are really impressive.  Also, most departments are friendly and understanding and want to see students succeed.
cons: Housing in Irvine is very expensive.  In addition parking can be a disaster.  That's all the cons I can think of.

pros: There is a great academic environment in UCI. Depending on which PI you work with, your research could be very fruitful. The career develop service is excellent. They provide free writing and networking workshops to post-doctoral fellows.
cons: The pay is low. You have to pay parking to go to work. Considering the nearby shopping mall parking is free and the low salary, it is expensive. Administrative paper works and purchasing requests could be handled very slowly.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Irvine, CA
pros: The faculty here are almost all well-received experts in their field, and interdisciplinary work is encouraged, which is a good boon.
cons: Management is full of red tape, and empty promises can be made by some members of management that are flat out denied by others.

pros: Working with the professors, staff, and peers is the best part about working at UC Irvine. Everyone is very supportive of one another and always encourage us to our best.
cons: One downside of being a teaching assistant at UC Irvine is that we succumb to high and constantly increasing housing.

review_title: No respect without an advanced degree
pros: Flexibility, Freedom, and Intellectual Stimulation
cons: Compensation, Bureaucracy, and Inflated Egos

review_title: It is what you make of it! (PhD in engineering review)
pros: Independence. If you work well on your own, you'll do great.
cons: If you struggle to self-motivate or seek out solutions yourself, you may find yourself feeling alone. Faculty will not save you unless you save yourself.

job_title: Ph D Student in Irvine, CA
pros: State of the art facilities and cutting edge research institution combined with capable and hard working faculty and staff. Newer university open to new and innovative ideas when it comes to student involvement and teaching.
cons: Does not offer an adequate level of social networking for both students and academia. More networking opportunities among students could foster and stronger sense of pride for the school and stimulate a better Alumni network in the future.

job_title: Graduate Research Student and Teaching Assistant in Irvine, CA
pros: The staff and and advisors are very supportive and professional.  The work being done is highly relevant and engaging/
cons: Wok moves very slowly.  There is a large issue with getting Purchase Orders and Work orders done in a timely fashion.

review_title: Bad Food, Poor Spirit and Culture
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Irvine, CA

cons: The food is very bad compared to UCSD or UCLA. There is no School Spirit. The number of international students is so high that everyone segregates. We should be fostering a feeling of inclusiveness, belonging, and assimilation.

job_title: Residential Data Coordinator in Irvine, CA
pros: Great school, lots of oppurtunities to work in different departments, very safe campus with lots of nature, friendly staff and motivated students

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Irvine, CA
pros: Research is strong here, and a good fit for anyone very interested in academic research.
cons: The department I worked in had a huge turnover rate in their administration. As a result, it was a mess in the office and clerical things took far too long.

pros:
Very good pay for International students. 
Good experience at teaching 
Very good pay for International students. 
Good experience at teaching
cons:
Too much work to handle with the coursework and graduate research.

Too much work to handle with the coursework and graduate research.

This campus definitely fostered a creative and out of the box thinking in regards to my research, which I've struggled to find at other institutions I've visited for research. Also, the graduate student housing make the area very affordable compared to the surrounding area.
cons: It never rains, or snows. Sometimes there are heavy winds.

pros: Zero crime, beautiful campus, great faculty, amazing weather and location. In my department, the professors are very accommodating and strike a good work-life balance. Overall I've thoroughly enjoyed my time here.
cons: Irvine is known as being "boring" but I don't quite agree with that assessment. Yes, there isn't a large nightlife compared to LA or even Newport, but luckily for Irvine residents, those two cities are relatively close by.

pros: Flexible hours, understanding management. You learn on the spot, especially for MacBook repairs. No prior knowledge necessary, but some is strongly preferred.

pros:

pros: Decent professors and courses. It's not the best at everything but not the worse either. It doesn't offer some courses compared to other higher ranked colleges but it's a good start.

cons: It's not a full time position which is disappointing, but that's the only con I could think of

review_title: Always good to work at a university

Staff and coworkers care for your well-being and personal development
Working with students very fulfilling

Student worker positions tend to go beyond regular hours of 9-5pm and so there was a difficult work life balance
Strong focus on politically correct/inclusive speech can lead wrongful alienation to people who make verbal mistakes even though they don't come from bigoted backgrounds

pros: Small department that is open to collaboration and sharing equipment. There is a good amount of space per faculty member

review_title: Magnificent place to work, the people are great and the environment is always charming and enthusiastic!
job_title: Shuttle Bus Driver in Irvine, CA

cons: Difficult to manage work during the midterm and final seasons, no benefits, start at low wages with multiple requirements for raises.

pros: UC Irvine has a strong computational chemistry program with research groups covering a wide range from electronic structure to biological and atmospheric applications.
cons: Southern California can disguise the passing of time, 2 years are quickly gone. Moreover, one has to get out of Irvine. Buy car, go to LA. Sleep and work at UCI, go anywhere else for social/cultural life.

review_title: Given the nature of the part-time position, It's difficult to complain.

cons: No increase in responsibilities throughout the entire time I spent working there. Correspondingly, there was no increase in pay.

review_title: Great Peers, Terrible Management, Oppressive Work Environment in the Department of Environmental Health and Safety
pros: Wonderful, knowledgeable and hard-working peers, Location, University Setting.  Your peers will become long-time friends and you will grow professionally there, despite the oppressive managers.

review_title: My work pays for my continuing education, so it is not bad at all
pros: Flexible work hours, don't have to work that much.
cons: Pay is low, work is pretty boring.

review_title: I worked for three years as a composition instructor at UCI.

cons: As is increasingly common in higher education, getting work as an adjunct be unreliable, subject to review, and sometimes requires lots of work with little security and few or expensive benefits.

pros: Good environment, good location, good weather. Irvine is a nice place. UCI is a good school.

pros:
Great Benefits

High standards set overall/ beautiful campus in Irvine

Top down management style in my department

bullying is problem

pros: The environment is relatively easy going. The workload is not too heavy, and it is a very low stress place to work at. Pay is reasonable for the amount of work you do.

They really do strive to make it a better place for their employees and students.

pros: Wonderful, hard-working students! Lots of optional professional development opportunities. Vibrant campus community. Many opportunities for collaboration if you are pro-active. Excellent benefits.

we are paid on-time and I think more than normal salary for PhD student in other state universities in the US.

Administrative hassles.
Lack of public funding and its implications.
Working under some professors who at bad teachers.
